testcase: Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing
query:
title: Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing

question: Hi TypeSpec Discussion,
CI has been failing constantly for our PR ([Azure Load Testing\] Add 2025-03-01-preview Data-Plane APIs by Harshan01 · Pull Request #32585 · Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32585)) for Typespec Validation step. The logs show that we are missing the Go SDK configuration and I am able to produce this error locally as well. However, our service doesnt have a Go SDK and we are not planning to put it in scope right now. This check has suddenly started failing for our PRs, what should we do?
```
Executing rule：SdkTspConfigVa1idation
[SdkTspconfigVa1idation]：validation failed．
- Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes"．Please add "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes".
- Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject一spans“．Please add "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject一spans.
- Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir"．Please add "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir".
- Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir"．Please add"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir".
Please See https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info．
For additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation.
```
ground_truth:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#suppressing-sdktspconfigvalidation-rules
Suppressing go specific rules worked for me. Here's our suppression file:
```yml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
paths:
- tspconfig.yaml
rules:
- SdkTspConfigValidation
sub-rules:
- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes
- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans
- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir
- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir
reason: 'Azure Load Testing does not support a Go SDK currently'
```

query:
title: Conflicting @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi and missing-x-ms-identifiers errors

question: I have this PR: [Release aks fleet 2025 08 01 preview rebase 5 · Azure/azure-rest-api-specs@432d36e](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/actions/runs/19480146348/job/55749960774?pr=38867#step:4:527) which has recently starting failing Typespec validation due to two errors.
For my new array fields, if I do not include a decorator such as @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[<prop>])
to the array, I get this error:
```
error @azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager/missing-x-ms-identifiers: Missing identifying properties of objects in the array item, please add @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[<prop>]) to specify it. If there are no appropriate identifying properties, please add @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]).
```
However, if I add that decorator, I receive this error:
```
error @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi: Azure specs should not be using decorator "$extension" from @typespec/openapi or @azure-tools/typespec-autorest. They will not apply to other emitter.
> 28 |   @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[])
```
Is there an intermediary solution to resolve both of these conflicts or is it best to suppress these errors?
ground_truth:
You should NOT use @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]) in your Azure Resource Manager TypeSpec code. The no-openapi rule is strict: ARM specs must NOT use decorators from @typespec/openapi or @azure-tools/typespec-autorest, including $extension, because these are only processed by OpenAPI emitters and will break other emitters (like client SDKs).
For array properties, the correct approach is to use the @identifiers decorator from @azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager. This decorator is the ARM-compliant way to specify identifying properties for array items and will ensure that x-ms-identifiers is emitted in the generated OpenAPI as needed, without violating the no-openapi rule. If there are no identifying properties, you can use @identifiers([]) to indicate this.
Example:
```
@identifiers([])
myArrayField: MyItemType[];
```
If you use @identifiers, the ARM linter will recognize the array is correctly specified and will not require you to use the OpenAPI extension directly.
You should only suppress the error if you have a legitimate, ARM-approved reason (for example, for backwards compatibility or an explicit reviewer exemption). But for new fields and normal scenarios, always use the ARM-compliant decorators, NOT OpenAPI extensions.
Summary:
DO NOT use @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]) in ARM specs.
DO use @identifiers([]) or @identifiers(["propertyName"]) as appropriate for array items.
Suppression should only be used in rare, reviewer-approved cases, not as a general workaround.
This approach ensures your spec is future-proof, passes all ARM validation, and is compliant with Azure API guidelines.

testcase: Need help with what appear like False Positives in ARM PR
query:
title: Need help with what appear like False Positives in ARM PR

question: I have a PR open for ARM Review: [Initial changes for UAT-Prod parity and for fixing any PR issues. by amolda · Pull Request #25751 ·…](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25751)
This is currently already ARMSignedOff, but it is blocked due to TypeSpec validation.
I want to understand how to work around the only currently failing check related to Typespec Validation failure. Currently there is one failure related to hardware.json (autogenerated OpenAPI file) having been modified. But the changes to hardware.json are to prevent other linter errors. The change to add readOnly to provisioningState was needed, as without it the Swagger LintDiff check failed asking to make it readOnly, and these changes were suggested by the representative in the ARM Office hours to work around the error. The other change in hardware.json is to add example for Preview API, which is subscription level API. the example markup was not getting auto-generated in the swagger json, so it needed to be added manually to prevent another swagger check of missing example from failing. Need some guidance to work around these errors.
For these specific errors, not sure if there is a way to mark example files for subscription level API or suppress errors for these APIs, and also, any way to mark provisioningState readOnly in tsp file (note, the instance was already marked as readOnly, but the error is around marking the type as readOnly.
Thanks!
ground_truth:
You should NOT manually edit the autogenerated hardware.json file to work around TypeSpec or linter errors. Instead, you must address these issues at the TypeSpec source level and via configuration, following Azure TypeSpec best practices.
1.ProvisioningState Must Be ReadOnly: The LintDiff check for `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly` is triggered because the validation expects the type schema referenced by `provisioningState` to be `readOnly`, not just the property instance. The recommended (and officially supported) solution is to update your `tspconfig.yaml` to set:
```
options:
"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest":
use-read-only-status-schema: true
```
This ensures all `ProvisioningState` schemas are emitted as `readOnly`, resolving the LintDiff error at the TypeSpec emission layer and removing the need to edit the generated Swagger.
2.Missing Examples for Subscription-level APIs: The OpenAPI validation (ModelValidation) requires an example for each operation, including subscription-level (preview) APIs. If auto-generation tools like OAV are not generating examples for these, you must:
Manually add a valid example JSON file in the `examples/<api-version>/` folder of your TypeSpec project, ensuring the `operationId` matches your operation.
There is currently NO supported way to suppress example requirements in TypeSpec or Swagger for missing examples. Suppression can sometimes be done via labels (like `Approved-ModelValidation`) to unblock a PR, but the recommended approach is to provide at least one example per operation.
General Best Practices:
Do NOT edit the emitted Swagger (`hardware.json`). Always make changes at the TypeSpec or configuration level.
If you encounter TypeSpec validation failures, refer to the TypeSpec source, emitter options, or required supporting files (such as examples or suppressions.yaml for certain rule types). For LintDiff, suppressions must be done in `readme.md` or `suppressions.yaml` (for TypeSpecRequirement errors only, not LintDiff or example requirements).
Summary:
Set `use-read-only-status-schema: true` in `tspconfig.yaml` to resolve the `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly` error.
Add missing example files for all operations, including subscription-level ones, as there is no suppression for missing examples.
Never edit the generated OpenAPI files to workaround linter errors.
Let me know if you need guidance on creating an example file or configuring the emitter options.

testcase: Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models
ground_truth:
You should not suppress this LintDiff validation error. The error `RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel` indicates that your `SharingDetail` model is being interpreted as a resource model, but it does not contain the required ARM resource properties: `name`, `id`, and `type` (all marked as readOnly). According to Azure API and TypeSpec guidelines, all resource models must include these properties to be compliant.
Suppressing this error is not the correct approach—instead, you must fix your TypeSpec definition. Ensure that resource models either extend the appropriate common-types resource base model (such as `Resource`, `ProxyResource`, or `ExtensionResource`) or, if `SharingDetail` is not a resource, ensure it is not referenced in a way that causes it to be treated as one.
For suppressing LintDiff errors in general, you can add scoped suppressions in your `readme.md` following the guidance here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions. However, for this particular error, you are expected to fix your TypeSpec spec to meet the ARM requirements—not suppress it.
To resolve this:
If `SharingDetail` is a resource, extend from the correct base model and add `id`, `name`, `type` (all readOnly).
If it is not a resource, check where it is referenced in your operations or model hierarchy to ensure it is not being treated as a resource by the code generator.
